title: How to Make Chopsticks from a Yucca Stalk

steps.headline: If you live in the American Southwestern desert, finding a yucca plant can be as easy as walking into your backyard.
steps.description: Find a stalk that has already fallen to the ground; don't break down an upright stalk, because birds use them to perch and nest. The stalks vary in suitability; find one that is mostly smooth and not completely hollowed out by bees.

steps.headline: Using a hacksaw or other fine-toothed (probably no less than 18 teeth per inch) saw, cut a section about 7 to 12 inches (17.8 to 30.5 cm) long; longer for cooking, shorter for eating.

Using a non-serrated knife, split the piece in half: sitting and wearing a leather apron, hold the piece securely with your thighs while you press with the knife from the top, one hand on the knife handle and the other cupped over the top of the blade.
steps.description: Press lightly, working the blade side to side. Once the split starts, it usually continues fairly effortlessly.

steps.headline: Continue splitting into quarters and eighths, until you get a suitable size.
steps.description: Discard the pieces that didn't split well (they make good kindling wood).

steps.headline: When finished splitting the stick, you can whittle the pieces to any level of perfection you desire.
steps.description: The simplest way is to just make the "food" end of them rounded, and leave the rest as it is.

text: If you live in the American Southwestern desert, finding a yucca plant can be as easy as walking into your backyard. Find a stalk that has already fallen to the ground; don't break down an upright stalk, because birds use them to perch and nest. The stalks vary in suitability; find one that is mostly smooth and not completely hollowed out by bees. Using a hacksaw or other fine-toothed (probably no less than 18 teeth per inch) saw, cut a section about 7 to 12 inches (17.8 to 30.5 cm) long; longer for cooking, shorter for eating.  Using a non-serrated knife, split the piece in half: sitting and wearing a leather apron, hold the piece securely with your thighs while you press with the knife from the top, one hand on the knife handle and the other cupped over the top of the blade. Press lightly, working the blade side to side. Once the split starts, it usually continues fairly effortlessly. Continue splitting into quarters and eighths, until you get a suitable size. Discard the pieces that didn't split well (they make good kindling wood). When finished splitting the stick, you can whittle the pieces to any level of perfection you desire. The simplest way is to just make the "food" end of them rounded, and leave the rest as it is.
